# Coincidence Analysis (CNA)
<font size="4">
*Coincidence Analysis* (CNA) is a configurational comparative method (CCM) of causal inference and data analysis that is custom-built for multi-outcome structures. 

<br><div class="boxed">
This page presents some relevant literature on CNA and will inform about new developments, seminars, workshops etc. For more see the <a href="https://www.uib.no/en/cna">official CNA website</a> at the University of Bergen. </div>

</font>
<br>
<br>

* Indianapolis (via Zoom), Aug. 3-5, 2021, [*Introduction to Causal Modeling with Coincidence Analysis*](docs/course_outlineCNA.pdf)

* Arlington, 2019: [*Coincidence Analysis (CNA) Workshop at the D&I Conference*](http://compasss.org/event/pre-conference-workshop-on-coincidence-analysis-12th-annual-conference-on-the-science-of-dissemination-implementation-in-health/)

### Software
#### Base package **cna**
The **cna** package provides all the base functionalities required to analyze data by means of CNA.

* On 12/17/2021, version 3.3.0 of the **cna** R-package has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 06/14/2021, version 3.2.0 of the **cna** R-package has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 05/28/2021, version 3.1.0 of the **cna** R-package has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 11/06/2020, update 3.0.1 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 09/13/2020, version 3.0.0 of the **cna** R-package has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 05/20/2020, update 2.2.3 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 06/12/2019, update 2.2.2 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 08/09/2019, update 2.2.1 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 04/13/2019, update 2.2.0 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 06/13/2018, update 2.1.1 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).
* On 06/01/2018, version 2.1.0 of the **cna** R-package has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cna).


#### Add-on package **cnaOpt**
The **cnaOpt** package provides various functions for optimizing consistency and coverage scores of models of configurational comparative methods as CNA and QCA.

* On 12/17/2021, update 0.5.0 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cnaOpt).
* On 09/14/2020, update 0.2.0 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cnaOpt).
* On 09/12/2019, update 0.1.1 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cnaOpt).
* On 21/10/2019, version 0.1.0 of the **cnaOpt** R-package has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=cnaOpt).

#### Add-on package **frscore**
The **frscore** package provides functions for calculating the robustness of CNA/CCM models.

* On 01/10/2022, update 0.1.1 has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=frscore).
* On 07/22/2021, version 0.1.0 of the **frscore** R-package has been released on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=frscore).

<br>


### [Literature](https://www.zotero.org/groups/4567107/coincidence.analysis/library)
#### Methodological

The details of the most recent version of CNA, which is implemented in the **cna** package, are described here:

* M. Baumgartner and M. Ambühl (2021), cna: An R Package for Configurational Causal Inference and Modeling. R package vignette: The Comprehensive R Archive Network. https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/cna/vignettes/cna_vignette.pdf.

* M. Baumgartner and M. Ambühl (2020), <a href="https://doi.org/10.1017/psrm.2018.45">Causal Modeling with Multi-Value and Fuzzy-Set Coincidence Analysis</a>, <em>Political Science Research and Methods</em> 8, 526-542, doi: 10.1017/psrm.2018.45. Replication material at https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/YIEAF1; <a href="docs/fscna.pdf">[penultimate draft]</a> 


The following paper provides a theoretical introduction the functions of the **cnaOpt** package: 

* M. Baumgartner and M. Ambühl  (2021), <a href="https://doi.org/10.1177/0049124121995554">Optimizing Consistency and Coverage in Configurational Causal Modeling</a>, <em> Sociological Methods &amp; Research</em>. <a href="docs/ConCovOpt.pdf">[penultimate draft]</a>; <a href="docs/replication_ConCovOpt.R">Replication material</a>.


The following paper introduces the robustness measure implemented in the **frscore** package:

* V.P. Parkkinen and M. Baumgartner (2021), <a href="https://doi.org/10.1177/0049124120986200">Robustness and Model Selection in Configurational Causal Modeling</a>, <em> Sociological Methods &amp; Research</em>. <a href="docs/robustness.pdf">[penultimate draft]</a>


Older CNA versions are introduced/discussed here: 

* M. Baumgartner and A. Thiem (2015), <a href="http://journal.r-project.org/archive/2015-1/baumgartner-thiem.pdf">Identifying Complex Causal Dependencies in Configurational Data with Coincidence Analysis</a>, <em>The R Journal</em> 7, 176-184. <a href="docs/RJwrapper.pdf">[penultimate draft]</a>

* M. Baumgartner (2013), <a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/1525822X12462527">Detecting Causal Chains in Small-<i>N</i> Data</a>, <em>Field Methods</em> 25, 3-24. <a href="docs/small_chain.pdf">[penultimate draft]</a>

* M. Baumgartner (2009), <a href="http://www.springerlink.com/content/x0487831qk67h455/">Uncovering
Deterministic Causal Structures: A Boolean Approach</a>, <i>Synthese</i> 170, 71-96. <a href="http://rdcu.be/ugSn">[Springer Nature SharedIt]</a> <a href="docs/det_kluw2.pdf">[penultimate draft]</a> 

* M. Baumgartner (2009), <a href="http://smr.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/38/1/71">Inferring
Causal Complexity</a>, <i>Sociological Methods &amp; Research</i> 38, 71-101. <a href="docs/qca.pdf">[penultimate draft]</a>

#### PhD theses using or on CNA
* Kelly Coates, 2021 (Portland State), “Affecting Absenteeism Through School-Based Health Services Delivery: A Configurational Comparative Methods Study of Oregon's Public Secondary Schools.” 
    (First standalone use of CNA in an applied analysis in any doctoral-level dissertation in any subject.)
* Jessica Dodge, 2021 (USC), “Exploring the Social Determinants of Health in a Population with Similar Access to Healthcare: Experiences from United States Active-Duty Army Wives.”
    (First formal pairing of CNA and QCA in an applied analysis in any doctoral-level dissertation in any subject.)
* Christoph Falk, 2020 (University of Geneva), “Konfigurationales kausales Modellieren. Ein theoretisches Fundament und Verfahren für Kausalanalysen mit crisp-set Konfigurationen.”
* Rebecca Whitaker, 2019 (UNC-Chapel Hill), “A Study of Preventable Hospital Utilization Among Medicaid-Insured Pediatric Patients in North Carolina’s Federally Qualified Health Centers.”
    (First doctoral-level dissertation in the United States to prominently feature CNA in an applied analysis.)
* Rui Fernando Correia Ferreira, 2018 (Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, UFMG/Brazil), “Estratégia de influência: O ganho de vantagens competitivas de empresas em suas relações com o Estado”. [ENG: “Influence strategy: Gaining competitive advantages for companies in their relations with the State”]
* Sepheen Byron, 2022 (University of North Carolina – Chapel Hill). “State Medicaid Policy Levers Related to Successful Health Information Exchange Among Providers.”
